Award.AbstractNarration:
Following the example of the previous three successful Georgia Algebraic Geometry Symposia at the University of Georgia, this award will support participation in a cycle of three conferences rotating among major research universities in Georgia: Emory, University of Georgia, and Georgia Tech. The first conference will take place at Emory University on October 16-18, 2015. The second conference will take place at the University of Georgia in October 2016, and the third at Georgia Tech in October 2017. The aim is to sustain and grow collaborations between mathematicians in the Southeast, and to nurture a new and diverse generation of students and postdocs, by providing a regular series of exciting mathematical activities and a forum to meet peers and attend talks by leading experts in the field.

Algebraic geometry and arithmetic geometry are some of the most established and active areas of mathematics and have deep connections with many other subjects. In addition to their central role in mathematics, they have important applications in encryption, physics, engineering, biology, and a host of other sciences. The conferences will aim at presenting the latest advances in these fields to a wide audience of local researchers, students, and postdocs.

Symposium web site: http://research.franklin.uga.edu/gags/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to stimulate and strengthen the growing community of algebraic geometers in Georgia and the south which has seen increased ties since the start of the Georgia Algebraic Geometry Symposium in 2012.

The first conference was held at Emory University, from Friday afternoon October 23 until Sunday, October 25, 2015. Including the PI, eighty-five participants attended and there were nine speakers. The speakers included Valery Alexeev (University of Georgia), Brian Conrad (Stanford University), Brian Lehmann (Boston College), Max Lieblich (University of Washington), Alexander Merkurjev (UCLA), Alena Pirutka (Ecole Polytechnique), Aaron Pixton (Harvard University), Tony V?rilly-Alvarado (Rice University) and Olivier Wittenberg (CNRS - Ecole Normale Superieure).  The conference website is https://sites.google.com/site/galgeoms2015/.

The second conference was held at University of Georgia, March 3-5, 2017.  There were ninety-eight participants including eight speakers.  The speakers were Jarod Alper (University of Washington), Michel Brion (Institut Fourier, Grenoble, France), Emanuele Macri (Northeastern), Dmitri Orlov (Steklov Math Institute, Moscow, Russia), Giulia Sacc? (Stony Brook), Justin Sawon (UNC Chapel Hill), Burt Totaro (UCLA) and Jacob Tsimerman (University of Toronto).  The conference website is https://sites.google.com/site/galgeoms2017/home.

 The third and final conference out of the three planned conferences was held at the Georgia Institute of Technology, Feb. 23-25, 2018.  Of the one hundred participants, there were eight speakers. The speakers included Linda Chen (Swarthmore College), June Huh (Institute for Advanced Study), David Jensen (University of Kentucky), Jesse Kass (University of South Carolina), Lek-Heng Lim (University of Chicago), Kristin Shaw (Max Planck Institute Leipzig/University of Oslo), Andrew Snowden (University of Michigan), Padmavathi Srinivasan (Georgia Institute of Technology). The conference website is http://people.math.gatech.edu/~jrabinoff6/gags2018/.
